tldr: Q1 2025 revenue rose 4% QoQ to KRW 79.14T with operating profit of KRW 6.7T as DX strength offset weaker DS results from HBM softness. Management kept a cautious outlook for 2H recovery, increased shareholder returns, and highlighted AI, robotics, and advanced node investment priorities.
bullets: Revenue increased 4% QoQ to KRW 79.14T and operating profit rose to KRW 6.7T with an 8.4% margin.
DX revenue climbed 28% on flagship smartphones and high-end appliances, while DS revenue fell 17% due to deferred HBM demand.
CapEx was KRW 12.0T (DS KRW 10.9T, display KRW 0.5T) and the board declared a KRW 365 dividend with KRW 10T buyback in progress.
themes: HBM and AI memory cycle driving supply
Foundry utilization recovery at advanced nodes
Premium device mix supporting DX demand
Tariff and macro uncertainty influencing sourcing

segments.title: Device Solutions (DS)
points: Revenue declined 17% QoQ due to lower HBM sales and deferred AI demand.
Memory focused on servers and high-density products while managing profitability.

segments.title: Device eXperience (DX)
points: Revenue rose 28% QoQ driven by Galaxy S25 series and high-value home appliances.
Visual Display and Digital Appliances contributed to operating profit growth.

guidance.label: FY2025 outlook
guidance.note: AI server demand growth and on-device AI tailwinds

notes.title: Shareholder returns
points: Quarterly dividend of KRW 365 per share; Q1 payout of KRW 2.45T scheduled late May.
KRW 10T buyback plan underway with KRW 3T remaining in progress.

notes.title: R&D and sustainability
points: R&D spending rose 15% YoY to a record Q1 level.
Company ranked first in a global supply chain human rights assessment.

themes.title: Tariffs and supply chain
points: Management highlighted scenario planning and flexible global production to manage tariff volatility.
Flagship products are exempt from current reciprocal tariffs, with investigations ongoing.

themes.title: HBM recovery
points: HBM3E samples were shipped and gradual recovery is expected from Q2.
HBM4 development remains on track with 2H mass production plans.

top_questions.question: How will Samsung address tariff uncertainty?
top_questions.summary: The company plans to flex global production and focus on premium products to offset cost impacts.

top_questions.question: When does HBM demand recover?
top_questions.summary: HBM sales are expected to improve sequentially as HBM3E ramps and new GPU launches resume demand.

top_questions.question: What drove MX profitability gains?
top_questions.summary: Higher flagship mix, cost optimization, and lower component prices supported margins.

implications: HBM pause creates a near-term DS headwind but sets up a rebound with HBM3E/4 ramps.
DX premium mix and AI features protect margins amid macro uncertainty.
competitive_notes: Foundry aims to improve profitability by expanding orders across advanced and mature nodes.
forecast_hooks: Monitor HBM3E contribution starting Q2 and HBM4 timelines.
Track foldable and flagship mix as tariff pressure builds.

action_items: Validate HBM3E qualification progress with major GPU customers.
Track CapEx pacing versus DS demand signals.
open_questions: Timing for full HBM demand normalization after export control impacts.
Extent of tariff-related component cost increases for MX.
watch_next_quarter: Q2 DS rebound and HBM sales recovery.
DX margin durability as launch effects fade.
